Description: Body sherd of Chian black-figured Komast pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black (partly worn); part of possibly a rosette in added white white, above two white bands; below, possibly part of a lotus flower in white; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of female figure (torso, arms and hips remaining; with added red on belted chiton), to right; on left, part of daisy shaped rosette as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Lemos places this sherd in Group B of the Black Figure Komast chalices. On these chalices a rim pattern is always present and on some of them, short and wide pendant rosettes hang from it. This group is loosely connected with Group B and Group D of the Sphinx and Lion Style. As the sherds in this group are heavily dependant on the presence of a rim pattern, this sherd ought to be removed from Group B as there is no evidence of a rim pattern. Lemos also places this sherd in Group C of the Black Figure Komast Chalices. Unlike the other groups, this is not a coherent group. Most chalices in this group have a rim pattern, while filling ornament is absent and incision is very carefully and delicately executed. The presence of a rosette as a filling ornament ought to exclude this sherd from the group. For parallels, see Lemos no. 1468 from Emporio.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. V, no. 45)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 164, p. 170, p. 325, no. 1489, pl. 196)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1251) (phase 2)
Williams 1983 / Sophilos in the British Museum (p. 162 note 23)
